title: Grubers’ Tour of Flanders gallery: A tale of two greats
content:
Cyclist
Grubers’ Tour of Flanders gallery: A tale of two greats

And just like that, another Tour of Flanders is in the books. But it wasn’t just any old Ronde van Vlaanderen, Sunday’s races saw two imperious displays of greatness that will be remembered for a long time.

The best Classics specialist in the women’s peloton, Lotte Kopecky, was simply unbeatable, soloing clear of her competitors – most of whom were her teammates – to win back-to-back Rondes. Shortly before that, Tadej Pogačar did exactly what he said he needed to do and won his third different Monument. Just two left for the set and you wouldn’t bet against him.

Yes, their performances will be remembered in the future, but why wait? Let’s remember them now through the lenses of photographers Jered and Ashley Gruber.

Tour of Flanders 2023 women’s race highlights

How incredible would it be to have the actual Tour of Flanders go past your house?

How incredible would it be to have the actual Tour of Flanders go past your windmill? Unconfirmed whether it’s Tom watching on (miss you Tom).

Good to see British team Lifeplus-Wahoo on the front early on thanks to Maria Novolodskaia.

With the women’s race starting in Oudenaarde, it didn’t take long for the cobbles to kick in and for the cream to rise to the top.

And it rises very quickly in these parts.

Eventually four of the strongest rode away, three of which – Lotte Kopecky, Lorena Wiebes and Marlen Reusser – were from SD Worx, safe to say UAE Team ADQ’s Silvia Persico wouldn’t take a turn on the front.

At least Persico had a soigneur for company.

And the second group behind them had another SD Worx rider, Demi Vollering, making a nuisance of herself.

After Strade Bianche, Kopecky knew she should probably drop her teammates to be safe.

Wiebes was the first to go, and it was an impressive performance by the sprinter to make it that far with the front group.

Not that it looked like Kopecky was even trying. Is she breathing at all?

Eventually (quite quickly) Kopecky, who is from Rumst, Flanders – about 80km east of Oudenaarde – decided it was time to go.

And so Reusser, having been dropped by Kopecky, proceeded to join Vollering in disrupting any form of chase, although at this point it looks like Kasia Niewiadoma would just be happy to finish.

The closest to a pain face Kopecky showed all day, more a concentration face if anything.

Behind: pain (left) and pain (right).

Pain (right) and pain? Joy? Not sure what Vollering is going through here to be honest.

Anna Henderson was definitely in the pain group on her way to an impressive ninth. Also shoutout this kid on the right.

And shoutout this champion. Back-to-back Ronde winner, the peloton’s best Classics rider, Flanders’ greatest ever woman cyclist? Certainly.

‘Right, which way to Roubaix?’

Vollering outsprinted Elisa Longo Borghini to make it a one-two, and Reusser was just happy to celebrate her teammates. Hats all round.

Sadly Annemiek van Vleuten fell victim to the road and a spirited fight left her coming in the second bunch nearly four minutes back.

Zoe Bäckstedt (left) came home 56th on her debut, finishing with teammate Letizia Borghesi.

Tour of Flanders 2023 men’s race highlights

The men’s race started in Bruges this year after a few editions heading out from Antwerp.

How incredible would it be to have the actual Tour of Flanders go past your car wash?

How incredible would it be to have the actual Tour of Flanders go past your garage?

How incredible would it be to have the actual Tour of Flanders go past your apartment?

No prizes for guessing who the locals wanted to win.

There were a lot of heavy crashes early on, and Magnus Sheffield didn’t have much luck. Might as well stop for a chat while he waits for the team car.

Fun for all the family.

Not so fun when it takes 100km to establish a break, but you can be sure Belgian national champion and local lad Tim Merlier got some very loud cheers.

A very capable second group formed, a carrot or two dangling for the favourites to catch.

Despite the race being almost as long as Milan-San Remo with a hell of a lot harder parcours, Daan Hoole was enjoying himself.

Christophe Laporte is a very strong bicyclist. He has a big pain face. Tadej Pogačar looks like he’s in zone 1.

Cycling fans being cycling fans.

Slowly (very quickly) the much-anticipated ‘Big Three’ rode clear of the main bunch.

It’s hard to show steepness but the fact is that the Koppenberg is a wall.

Just three guys, hanging out, chilling.

Once the second group became the first, former World Champion Mads Pedersen went clear.

And a Mathieu van der Poel rocket launch left Wout van Aert out the back in a world of pain, otherwise known as Flanders.

Pogačar showing he might be human, but also that he definitely isn’t.

‘OH MY GOD, THIS REALLY HURTS.’

Not sure what the guy on the right is looking at or whether or not he can actually see better with his handmade binoculars.

Insert ‘it never gets easier, you just get faster’. A lot faster.

POV: you’re literally everyone, Pogačar is riding away from you.

Not that the guy chasing him wasn’t also very fast, Van der Poel has very long arms.

Don’t worry, it’s not that the fans don’t appreciate the weight of Neilson Powless finishing fifth on his debut, it’s just that there may or may not be a Belgian in a Red Bull helmet just behind.

Give me a G.

Give me an O.

Give me an A.

Give me a T. Van der Poel is actually very relieved that Pogačar can now leave this race alone.

Matteo Jorgenson looks like he’s seen things. The 23-year-old finished ninth on his debut.

Davide Ballerini was not lucky, he managed to crash into the barriers while leading out Tim Merlier in the sprint for – *checks notes* – 43rd.

Drink it in, it’s five days until Paris-Roubaix.

author: Will Strickson | Deputy Website Editor
